caption: A small museum in an historic building. Explanations are only in French which may be an issue for some, in anywise they are short. The focus is on the past and there are interesting exhibits. This does in no way compare to the Josephine in Vienna or the Vrolijk museum in Amsterdam. The building itself is also interesting. I would recommend visiting for people with an interest in the subject and enough time in Paris otherwise see the highlights of the city.
I really enjoyed this small but fantastic collection of medical history. There are some many instruments that make you sympathetic for the patient who had to suffer!

A small museum of historical medical instruments. Fascinating for those who that sounds interesting to - potentially horrifying for those who are squeamish. The building does not have AC, but the room was cool when I visited. It is located on the third floor, but there is an elevator if you turn right immediately after entering the main door.

This is hard to find museum but it is located on the third floor of the Université de Paris Cite. Cost is 3.50Euro for adults and $2.50 for minors. It is one large room with mostly ancient medical instruments.  It is certainly not one of the better museums for medicine that I have been too. All signage are in French.

Very nice place. It is amazing the stuff has not changed a lot. Good bit of history and the room has a nice look. The library was really cool to see too. The art on the walls was super interesting to see as well. Nothing like some Goat blood… Great visit!

An excellent museum that cover the history of the medical field. It is an ideal place to be visited by scholars, students, researchers and anyone who want to widen his/her knowledge about the development of medical equipment. A nice place for familes and friends who have the interest in Medical History!

A small museum with a strong cache of surgical instruments but also some interesting pieces. With the Dupeytron museum closed I was hoping some of it's displays would have been added here. Sadly not. Worth a visit if you have an interest in medical history, not expensive at $3.50 entry.

The exhibition itself is remarkable, but finding the place can be tricky - when entering the front door, turn right and locate the elevator. Take it to the second floor and around the corner (stairs will be to your right), you'll find the museum. The cashier will love you to pieces if you bring exact change (adult ticket is 7€). I suggest downloading a translator app (I used google translate) as all the signs are in french.

This is just sad: such a great idea for a museum, and just no audioguide or text in english. Even a sketch of how these old medical devices were used could have made a huge difference. Until they'll change it, i can't recommend this place. Also, it's small and takes less than 30min
Small but fascinating museum! A true gem
It's a very cool museum but very small, the price is fair. A good amount of medical memorabilia. Interesting to see how the apparel was in the past and imagine the surgeries and procedures.

Small museum with smaller hours.. but if you are into old school medical equiptment that resembles medevial torture devices- this museum is for you! Ever wonder how a pair of human ears can be used to decorate furniture? Don't forget to check out the side table constructed with human body parts!  I enjoyed the walk around the medical school almost as much as the museum, I was even allowed to peak into the beautiful library.
Small but interesting. There is no audio guide and everything was in french so make sure you can use a photo translation app.
Very small but may be worth a visit if you're nearby.  Interesting to get a glimpse of old equipment
I think today they decided to take an unplanned most probably paid break! It wasn't mentioned anywhere. On the entrance door it says just library is closed! Perfect communication...
I was happy! I think it’s one of the best places in Paris, especially who like medicine
It.is interesting but spend a day translating the descriptions to English, even if it is just vopy paste from Google Translate. Will make the visit more intetesting for tourists.
What a special place! Perfect for a stolen hour on a rainy afternoon to get your fill of some pretty horrid, historical and medical equipment!
Extremely fascinating museum!!! A hidden (and a bit macabre) gem in Paris. Very affordable as well... kind of tucked away, which meant it wasn't crowded so that's a huge plus.
Highly recommend this small but detailed collection of historical medical devices and period techniques. Small fee to enter but worth the value. Limited hours so plan accordingly.
Hard to find, a little small, but top quality. They have one of those famous tables made of petrified human remains.
Very interesting, I learned a lot. Low price. The whole building is a museum itself.

A great place for the lovers of medicine and history! Not included in the Paris Museum Pass, but the entrance is only €3,50. All the items have identification plate and many have little texts explaining the history, previous owner and usage. They have permanent and temporary exhibitions. It’s a unique place in Paris and a museum like no other in the city.

Very small and modest gallery (I don't call it as a museum) in only 1 single salle exhibiting exclusively few medical tools. It has nothing to do with its name "history". While visiting this place you won't learn anything about the "history" of medicine. Very modest.. I don't recommend
If you're interested in the human body and all the history of medicine,  you will discover a lot of interesting things. It's not a big museum but the ticket is cheap and worthwhile!
Small museum, one large room but full of nice artefacts and tools. You should spend less than an hour in it.

The museum is closed from today, July 26 until September. Yep, you read that correctly. September. I am not joking. Came all the way into Paris to visit the museum today only to be shown the printed notice and turned away.

It is a small museum, but very interesting, specially if you like the medical area. You pay 3,50€ to enter and it is basically one room. It takes around 1h (you can do it faster or slower if you want). The only down point in my opinion is that the signs explaining the pieces are only in French. It wouldn't be hard to put signs also in English so we wouldn't have to be using Google translate or guessing all the time...

If you like medical things, you’ll love this museum. It’s full of old devices. Explanations are in French only so bring Google lens with you. About a quarter of the display area is closed off and it’s super hot when temps outside are hot.

Takes about 30mins to walk around. Have an audio guide, so you understand what's going on. Loads of different medical instruments to look at. Very well set out and very clean. Not guided so able to go at your own pace and admire for as long as you want. Worth a visit. Cheaper tickets for students and children available. Plenty of parking outside the front for free.

Very beautiful, historical, and informative museum. It is not large, but is worth the visit. The museum's artifacts placards are in French only, so would probably be less informative if cannot read French. That said, I do believe that just viewing the items, you can probably interpret what most are, and would be fascinating to view in and of themselves. There was an upstairs area that was closed when I attended, so I  not sure what was in that area on display. However, they have old Egyptian tools, the history of optical, dental, nephrological, electrical, gynecological, etcetera items.
Thank goodness for modern medicine! The antique instruments were fascinating yet painful looking.

I ve wanted to visit  this museum so much that I extended my stay in paris just to be able to visit it. However, it needs at least an english tranlation to the objects shown. Also, the only 2 female figures that were exposed in this beautiful museum had no tagged information about them.Not even their name.So ,we had to ask the polite lady,who was more than happy to explain to us what those 2 important women were!So ,it would be a good idea to add the  information about them .Thank you for everything
Nice small museum
Very interesting small museum, absolutely worth a visit. Just check the opening times, as it is not open that often. You also need cash to go in for what we could understand.

Very interesting museum is you're into such museums. A lot of interesting instruments from 15th century onwards. Some are quite disturbing and painful just to look at. But still interesting and thrilling. Unfortunately all the signs are in French.

I've seen a lot of medical museums (like 50+ medical museums it's a thing I have). The collection isn't the best annotated, but it's superbly collected and in a stunning setting. One of the best osteotome collections I've ever seen.
Very exciting to come before the closed doors, while it is stated that the museum is open :)
